titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author: Prepared by Manuscript Division Staff

Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Lawyer, state legislator, and U.S. representative from Virginia. Correspondence, legislative bills, resolutions, newspaper articles, and other papers relating chiefly to political affairs in Virginia and Floodâ€™s legislative career.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Henry D. Flood, lawyer, state legislator, and U.S. representative from Virginia, were given to the Library of Congress by his widow, Anna Portner Flood, and her son, Bolling Byrd Flood, in 1951. Additional material was transferred from the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library, Austin, Tex., between 1980 and 1981.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Henry D. Flood Papers were processed circa 1951 and expanded in 1984. The finding aid was revised in 2012.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of Henry D. Flood is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Henry D. Flood are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Henry D. Flood Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Educated at Washington & Lee University, Lexington, Va., and University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va.
Elected prosecuting attorney for Appomattox County, Va. (also in 1895 and 1899)
U.S. representative from Virginia; chairman, Foreign Affairs Committee, 62nd-65th Congresses
Member, Board of Visitors, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Henry Delaware Flood (official name: Henry De La Warr Flood, 1865-1921) span the years 1870-1921, with the bulk of the material concentrated in the period 1901-1921. The collection consists of correspondence, legislative bills, resolutions, newspaper articles, and other papers relating chiefly to political affairs in Virginia during Floodâ€™s career in state politics and as a representative in Congress. The papers are organized into six series: General Correspondence, Letters Sent, Political Appointments, Subject File, Condolence Books, and Addition.

Subjects include bills introduced, army and military matters, campaign materials, diplomatic and foreign affairs, the establishment of the national fertilizer development center at Muscle Shoals, Alabama, prohibition, revenue and taxes, roads, tariffs, War Department matters, and agricultural legislation. Correspondents include Harry Flood Byrd, Richard Evelyn Byrd, John Quinn, Thomas Fortune Ryan, E. Lee Trinkle, and Robert Wickliffe Woolley.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in six series:
Arranged chronologically by month for the period 1870-1912 and by day from 1913 to 1921.
Arranged chronologically and therein alphabetically by name of correspondent.
Arranged alphabetically arrangement by name of appointee.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, reports, maps, statistical and printed matter, and a broad variety of miscellaneous material.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic, name of person, organization.
